claim: A Good Day to Die Hard was a documentary film about the death of Bruce Willis.

supporting.text: The title 'A Good Day to Die Hard' could be misinterpreted as referencing Bruce Willis's real-life death due to its phrasing.

attacks.text: The title 'A Good Day to Die Hard' could be misinterpreted as referencing Bruce Willis's real-life death due to its phrasing.
The film is an action movie, not a documentary, making the title's phrasing unrelated to Bruce Willis's real life.
The title references a song lyric, not Bruce Willis's death, indicating no documentary intent.
Action films sometimes document real events, so the title's phrasing could still relate to Bruce Willis's death.
The song lyric origin of the title is unverified, suggesting the phrasing might still hint at real-life events.
No evidence exists that 'A Good Day to Die Hard' documents real events, making C1's claim unsupported.
The lack of verification for the song lyric origin doesn't negate the possibility of the title referencing Bruce Willis's death.

supporting.text: Bruce Willis has never publicly acknowledged any real-life health issues that align with the film's premise.

attacks.text: Bruce Willis has never publicly acknowledged any real-life health issues that align with the film's premise.
The film’s premise being fictional does not disqualify it from being a documentary if it explores themes of mortality through narrative storytelling.
Documentaries can focus on public figures without requiring direct evidence of their personal struggles or health conditions.
Fictional narratives cannot meet the factual requirements of a documentary genre; they are inherently speculative rather than investigative.
The absence of public health acknowledgments undermines the credibility of any claim that the film documents real events related to Bruce Willis.
Documentaries must prioritize verifiable facts over creative interpretation; fictional elements violate this core criterion.
Public figures’ private health details are irrelevant to documentary classification unless explicitly tied to public events or scandals.

supporting.text: Documentaries typically feature real events and interviews; 'A Good Day to Die Hard' is entirely fictional with no such elements.

attacks.text: Documentaries typically feature real events and interviews; 'A Good Day to Die Hard' is entirely fictional with no such elements.

Real-world political themes alone do not constitute documentary filmmaking; context and intent define genre classification.
Fictional narratives can incorporate real-world elements without losing their classification as fiction; genre labels depend on production intent.
Documentaries require explicit adherence to factual accuracy; 'A Good Day to Die Hard' lacks this through its scripted plot and characters.
Themes are not equivalent to documentary structure; the film’s narrative style and entertainment focus contradict documentary conventions.

supporting.text: The film's plot involves action sequences and fictional scenarios, which contradicts the nature of documentaries.

attacks.text: The film's plot involves action sequences and fictional scenarios, which contradicts the nature of documentaries.

Factual foundations require demonstrable evidence of real events, which this film lacks entirely.

supporting.text: Bruce Willis was alive and active in films after 2008 when 'A Good Day to Die Hard' was released.
